docs.lead_paragraph: For the last two weeks, Moscow Hospital No. 6, a nine-story brown-brick building on the outskirts of the city, has been the center of a desperate effort to treat the most seriously afflicted victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. Soviet and American doctors and an Israeli specialist, using equipment and drugs airlifted from around the world, have raced against the killing effects of radiation exposure in an attempt to save the lives of 33 men and 2 women who spent the first hours after the April 26 accident within yards of the damaged reactor. One of the American physicians, Dr. Robert Peter Gale of the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles, said that as of Wednesday evening 7 of the 35 had died of radiation and 28 remained alive. Higher Figure Reported Tonight, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in a nationally televised address that the death toll had risen to 9 - 2 killed in the original explosion and 7 who have died since of radiation. He said that ''as of today'' 299 people had been hospitalized with radiation disease of varying degrees. That figure was 95 more than reported by Soviet officials last week.

headline.main: U.S. DOCTORS IN SOVIET FACE A 'BATTLEFIELD'

byline.original: By PHILIP TAUBMAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to allow the export of American-made drugs awaiting approval as safe and effective for domestic sale. The bill, which proponents argue would preserve America's lead in biotechnology while not exposing foreign consumers to unsafe or ineffective drugs, passed on a vote of 91 to 7. The measure, which has the support of the Reagan Administration, now goes to the House.
